lead_paragraph: A growing Republican-led movement is pushing the federal government to hand the states millions of acres of Western public lands — as well as their rich stores of coal, timber and grazing grass.

byline.contributor: Jack Healy reported from Denver, and Kirk Johnson from Burns, Ore. Julie Turkewitz contributed reporting from Denver.
byline.original: By JACK HEALY and KIRK JOHNSON

snippet: A growing Republican-led movement is pushing the federal government to hand the states millions of acres of Western public lands — as well as their rich stores of coal, timber and grazing grass.

headline.main: The Larger, but Quieter Than Bundy, Push to Take Over Federal Land
headline.print_headline: A Quieter Push to Get Control of U.S. Lands

abstract: Growing number of lawmakers in Western states, most of them Republican, are pushing for federal government to give millions of acres of public lands back to states; while they have criticized armed ranchers and activists who have seized control of wildlife refuge in Oregon, goals are essentially same; critics of concept note proponents are not giving clear picture of what would happen if states do take back federal lands inside their borders.
